validation_metadata.verified_by: Claude Code AI Assistant - Manual Extraction
validation_metadata.verification_method: Complete manual review of 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.

rights_of_access.description: It is the public policy of Illinois that all persons are entitled to full and complete information regarding affairs of government. All records in custody of a public body are presumed open to inspection or copying.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies unless specifically exempted by statute; burden on agency to justify withholding
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Strong statutory presumption - access is the rule, withholding is the exception requiring justification
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert: 'Under 5 ILCS 140/1 and 140/3, Illinois presumes all public records are open. Please provide access pursuant to this statutory presumption.'

rights_of_access.description: Requests may be submitted via personal delivery, mail, fax, or email. Public bodies must accept requests through multiple electronic and traditional channels.
rights_of_access.conditions: No specific form required; multiple submission methods accepted; request must be in writing
rights_of_access.applies_to: All FOIA requests to Illinois public bodies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Modern accessibility - requesters can use email or fax rather than only mail or in-person delivery
rights_of_access.request_tips: Submit via preferred method: 'I am submitting this FOIA request by [email/fax/mail] as authorized by 5 ILCS 140/3.'

rights_of_access.description: Public bodies cannot require requesters to state their purpose for requesting records, except for commercial requests which must include a statement of purpose.
rights_of_access.conditions: Purpose statement prohibited except for commercial use; no justification needed for non-commercial requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Protects requester privacy and prevents agencies from judging worthiness of request; commercial requests are exception
rights_of_access.request_tips: If asked for purpose: '5 ILCS 140/3 prohibits requiring a purpose statement except for commercial requests. My request is not commercial, so no purpose statement is required.'

rights_of_access.description: Public bodies must respond to FOIA requests within 5 business days after receipt. Response must either comply with or deny the request, or notify requester of extension.
rights_of_access.conditions: 5 business days from receipt; response required (cannot ignore); must grant, deny, or extend
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Business days only; quick turnaround required; failure to respond within 5 days allows deemed denial
rights_of_access.request_tips: Track deadline: '5 ILCS 140/3(c) requires response within 5 business days from receipt. Please confirm receipt date and expected response date.'

rights_of_access.description: Public bodies may extend response time by up to 5 additional business days with written notice to requester explaining reasons for extension. Maximum total response time is 10 business days.
rights_of_access.conditions: Extension requires written notice; must state reasons for delay; limited to one 5-day extension (total 10 days)
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Extension must be justified - agencies cannot automatically extend; requester must receive written explanation
rights_of_access.request_tips: If extended: '5 ILCS 140/3(e) permits one 5-day extension with written notice and explanation. Please provide written justification for this delay and confirm 10-day total deadline.'

rights_of_access.description: The first 50 pages of black and white, letter or legal size copies are provided free of charge. This is one of the strongest fee protections in the nation.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to first 50 pages only; must be black and white; letter or legal size; subsequent pages charged at $0.15 each
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Virtually all small/medium requests are completely free; eliminates cost barrier for typical citizen requests
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert free copies: '5 ILCS 140/6(a) provides the first 50 pages free of charge. There should be no fee for this request [if 50 pages or less].'

rights_of_access.description: After the free first 50 pages, additional black and white copies are charged at $0.15 per page maximum. This caps fees for larger requests.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to pages 51+; black and white only; letter or legal size; actual cost for color or non-standard sizes
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: For 100-page request: pages 1-50 free + pages 51-100 at $0.15 = $7.50 total. Very affordable even for large requests.
rights_of_access.request_tips: For large requests: 'Under 5 ILCS 140/6(a), pages 51+ are capped at 15¢ each. My estimated cost is [calculate based on 50 free + $0.15 per additional page].'

rights_of_access.description: Public bodies must provide records in electronic format when requested. Electronic records provided at actual cost of medium (typically minimal).
rights_of_access.conditions: Requester must request electronic format; fee limited to actual cost of medium (CD, USB, email, etc.)
rights_of_access.applies_to: Public records maintained or producible electronically
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Electronic delivery should be cheapest option; agencies must accommodate electronic format requests
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request electronic: 'Under 5 ILCS 140/6(b), please provide these records in electronic format [PDF/Excel/native format] at actual cost of medium.'

rights_of_access.description: Requesters may seek review by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) within 60 days of denial. PAC is independent position in Attorney General's office providing binding determinations on FOIA disputes.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must file within 60 days of denial; PAC provides binding review (with limited exceptions); free administrative process
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Unique oversight - Illinois PAC issues binding decisions, not just advisory opinions; accessible at 1-877-299-FOIA
rights_of_access.request_tips: Appeal to PAC: 'I will seek review by the Public Access Counselor under 5 ILCS 140/9.5 if this denial is not reconsidered. PAC provides binding determinations.'

rights_of_access.description: Court may award reasonable attorney's fees and costs to prevailing requesters in FOIA litigation. Makes judicial enforcement financially viable.
rights_of_access.conditions: Requester must prevail in court action; fees and costs must be reasonable; court discretion
rights_of_access.applies_to: Prevailing parties in Illinois FOIA litigation
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Fee-shifting provision encourages compliance and makes enforcement accessible; agencies risk paying requester's legal costs if they lose
rights_of_access.request_tips: Warn of fees: '5 ILCS 140/11(i) provides for attorney fees and costs if I prevail in court. Please reconsider to avoid potential liability for my legal expenses.'

rights_of_access.description: Public bodies that willfully and intentionally violate FOIA may be subject to civil penalties ranging from $2,500 to $5,000 per violation.
rights_of_access.conditions: Violation must be willful and intentional; penalties per violation; imposed by court; PAC may recommend penalties
rights_of_access.applies_to: Public bodies that deliberately violate FOIA
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Significant penalties discourage intentional violations; multiple violations can result in substantial cumulative penalties
rights_of_access.request_tips: Reference penalties: '5 ILCS 140/11(j) imposes civil penalties up to $5,000 for willful FOIA violations. Please ensure compliance.'

rights_of_access.description: When records contain both exempt and non-exempt information, agencies must redact exempt portions and provide access to remaining non-exempt information.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies when records are partially exempt; requires redaction of only exempt portions; non-exempt parts must be disclosed
rights_of_access.applies_to: All requests where records contain mixed content
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies cannot withhold entire document because one paragraph is exempt; must separate and disclose public portions
rights_of_access.request_tips: Demand segregable portions: '5 ILCS 140/7(2) requires redaction and disclosure of non-exempt portions. Please provide redacted records showing what specific information is being withheld.'

rights_of_access.description: Audio recordings of open meetings must be made available to the public. Meeting minutes and recordings are subject to FOIA.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to recordings of open public meetings; subject to standard FOIA procedures
rights_of_access.applies_to: Public meetings of Illinois public bodies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Meeting transparency - recordings provide verbatim record of government decision-making; complements Open Meetings Act
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request meeting records: 'Please provide audio recordings and minutes of [specific meeting] as public records under Illinois FOIA.'

rights_of_access.description: In administrative and judicial review, the burden is on the public body to demonstrate that requested records are exempt from disclosure.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies in PAC review and court proceedings; agency must prove exemption applies; requester need not prove entitlement
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Burden-shifting removes obstacle for requesters - you don't have to prove you deserve records; agency must prove they can withhold
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge denial: 'Under 5 ILCS 140/11, your agency bears the burden of proving these records are exempt. Please provide detailed legal justification.'

rights_of_access.description: For commercial requests, public bodies must respond within 21 working days. May extend up to additional 10 business days with notice.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies only to commercial requests; 21 working days (longer than standard 5 days); 10-day extension available; commercial requester must state purpose
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Separate timeline for commercial use; allows agencies more time for commercial requests that may be more burdensome
rights_of_access.request_tips: For commercial requests: '5 ILCS 140/3.1 provides 21 working days for commercial request response. Please respond within this statutory timeline.'

rights_of_access.description: Each public body must designate one or more officials or employees to receive FOIA requests and must publicly display contact information for Freedom of Information officers.
rights_of_access.conditions: Contact information must be publicly available; designated FOIA officers required; ensures requesters know where to submit requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Creates accountability and accessibility - requesters can easily identify proper contact for FOIA requests
rights_of_access.request_tips: If unclear who to contact: 'Please provide contact information for your FOIA officer as required by 5 ILCS 140/3.5.'

rights_of_access.description: Courts may order immediate disclosure of wrongfully withheld records and may enjoin public bodies from withholding public records.
rights_of_access.conditions: Available when court finds improper withholding; court can compel prompt production; injunctive relief available
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Courts have authority to order immediate compliance rather than allowing prolonged withholding during appeals
rights_of_access.request_tips: In court: 'Request immediate disclosure order under 5 ILCS 140/11 if court finds records were improperly withheld.'
